div.p: The first study of the local interstellar medium (LISM) toward Puppis-Vela (lğ‘™italic-ll = 245Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg to 275Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg, bğ‘italic-bb = -ADDOP:minus-15Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg to +5Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg, d <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc) is presented in this paper. A study of the locations, sizes, and physical characteristics of local interstellar gas, i.e. â€œastronephography,â€ is included, and relies upon the improved distance measurements provided by Hipparcos parallax measurements. All spectra of more distant sight lines contain absorption features due to intervening local gas, and more distant structures can only be studied accurately if components due to the LISM have been isolated. Towards this end, high resolution (R â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 95,000), high signal-to-noise (S/N âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 110 to 250) Na i Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambdaÎ»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda5889.951, 5895.924 spectra of 11 nearby stars in the direction of Puppis-Vela have been obtained with the CoudÃ© Echelle Spectrograph on the 1.4 meter CoudÃ© Auxiliary Telescope at the European Southern Observatory. Toward Puppis-Vela, absorption due to the Local Interstellar Cloud (LIC) was not observed, but components at three distinct velocities were found, and the extent of the local gas producing the features was estimated. The three components have the following locations and velocities: Component Aâ€”[lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 276Â°Â to 298Â°, bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-5Â°Â to +4Â°], Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +6 to +9 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 104 pc; Component Bâ€”[lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 264Â°Â to 276Â°, bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-7Â°Â to +3Â°], Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +12 to +15 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 115 pc; Component Câ€”[lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 252Â°Â to 271Â°, bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-8Â°Â to -ADDOP:minus-6Â°], Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +21 to +23 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 131 pc. The conclusions regarding the ultraviolet spectrum of Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel (lğ‘™italic-ll = 263Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg, bğ‘italic-bb = -ADDOP:minus-8Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg, d = 258Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pm35 pc) presented by Fitzpatrick & Spitzer (1994) were re-examined in light of this new LISM data, and the ambiguity in their conclusions about several absorption components is resolved. The stars in Puppis-Vela flank the region of the apparent extension of the Local Bubble (or Cavity) known as the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel, and measurements of the Na i column density towards the sample stars have been used to modify existing estimates of the extent of the tunnel. A compilation of all existing Na i observations of <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc sight lines around the tunnel reveal that low column densities have been exclusively detected within lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 210Â°Â to 250Â°, and bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-21Â°Â to -ADDOP:minus-9Â°. Near the Galactic plane, at latitudes -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< 0Â°Â and d â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 150 pc, the tunnel is confined to l <RELOP:less-than< 270Â°, a lower longitude than was previously reported.

article.div: ISM: kinematics & dynamics â€” ISM: structure â€” Galaxy: solar neighborhood

div.p: We view the Universe through local interstellar gas and this gaseous material in the immediate vicinity of the Sun affects all absorption line studies of more distant Galactic lines of sight.

The Local Interstellar Medium (LISM) in the direction of Puppis-Vela [lğ‘™italic-ll = 250Â°Â to 275Â°, bğ‘italic-bb = -ADDOP:minus-15Â°Â to +5Â°] was selected for a Na i absorption line study to determine the kinematics of large-scale structures in the interstellar medium (ISM) toward Puppis-Vela, and was initiated by Sahu & Blaauw (1994). Within âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 2 kpc in this direction, three large structures have been identified (1) the Vela Molecular Ridge at âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 1 kpc (Murphy & May 1991), (2) the IRAS Vela Shell at âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 450Â pc (Sahu, 1992) and (3) the 36âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ}-diameter, HÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha emitting Gum Nebula. Na i absorption caused by local (d <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc) interstellar gas is present in spectra toward the distant background stars embedded in and beyond these extended objects. The absorption components arising within 200Â pc must first be identified and understood before attempting to study the kinematics of more distant ISM structures. This work is the first attempt to three dimensionally (l,b,d) place components of interstellar gas in a localized region on the sky using optical absorption spectroscopy, and is preliminary to mapping clouds and extended structures at larger distances. The only interstellar clouds that have been mapped three dimensionally are the Local Interstellar Cloud (LIC) and G-cloud (Linsky et al. 2000) using principally H column densities from Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) and Goddard High Resolution Spectrograph (GHRS) spectra and the assumption that the clouds have constant density. For the Puppis-Vela sightlines discussed here, the technique of Linsky et al. cannot be applied since the Sun is not embedded in the gas under study and there is no evidence to allow the assumption that the lines of sight have constant density. Distances to target stars derived from Hipparcos parallax measurements allow limits to be placed on the extent of interstellar gas components, the first step in mapping the interstellar clouds or understanding the â€œastronephographyâ€ (Linsky et al. 2000) of the region. With multiple sight lines at various distances, recurring velocity features may be identified and used as a basis for defining the locations, sizes, and characteristics of interstellar gas.

Little is known about the LISM in Puppis-Vela within âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 200Â pc. In total, absorption line spectra of only five Puppis-Vela lines of sight have been published (Crawford 1991; Dunkin & Crawford 1999; Ferlet et al. 1985 and Welsh et al. 1994). There has be no localized, systematic study of the local gas toward Puppis-Vela until now. One implication of this lack of information is that LISM data must be obtained from all sky surveys (Welsh it et al. 1998, GÃ©nova it et al. 1997) whose velocity and column density generalizations may not be indicative of the nature of LISM gas in a specific direction. The identification of local velocity components toward Puppis-Vela performed here will allow local absorption features to be distinguished from more distant absorption features in any subsequent study of the ISM in Puppis-Vela. Questions posed by Puppis-Vela ISM studies that are addressed here include: What is the contribution of the LIC in this direction? Does the Local Bubble (or Cavity) extend beyond âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 70Â pc in this direction? Are there any neutral velocity components in the LISM in Puppis-Vela?

We investigate the kinematics and structure of the LISM gas in Puppis-Vela using Na i absorption line data of 11 stars with Hipparcos-based distances <RELOP:less-than< 200Â pc, in conjunction with data for five previously studied lines of sight. The Na i spectra presented here form a subset of a larger sample containing absorption spectra toward âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 75 more distant stars in Puppis-Vela, which corroborate the conclusions made here, and will be presented in a subsequent paper.

It is helpful to review the structures contained in the LISM to more fully understand the Puppis-Vela lines of sight. The three known components of the LISM include the Local Interstellar Cloud (LIC), the G cloud, and the Local Bubble. The Sun is moving through a warm (T âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 7000Â K), low density (n(H i) âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 0.1cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}), partially ionized interstellar cloud termed the LIC (Lallement & Ferlet 1997, Lallement & Bertin 1992). FigureÂ 1 shows a schematic diagram of the components of the LISM as viewed from above the plane of the Galaxy. The LIC is observed in projection toward most but not all nearby stars, and extends approximately 3 â€“ 8Â pc. The LIC is the only interstellar cloud where in situ measurements of interstellar dust grains (Baguhl et al. 1996) and interstellar gas (Witte et al. 1992) have been performed through Ulysses & Galileo spacecraft observations. Models of the LIC (Redfield & Linsky 1999) place the Sun just inside the LIC, in the direction of the Galactic Center and toward the North Galactic Pole. The Solar Wind is carving out a cavity in the LIC which is slightly elongated in the direction of relative motion of the Sun in the LIC. In the direction of the Galactic Center, another cloud termed the G cloud is seen. This cloud is colder (T âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 5400Â K) (Linsky & Wood 1996) and is approaching the Sun at about 29 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. From Figure 1, it is clear that the G cloud is not expected to be seen in the Puppis-Vela direction. Since the Sun is within the LIC, interstellar sight lines in all directions contain absorption from gas associated with the LIC, but these features are not always strong enough to be detected in Na i absorption. Specifically toward Puppis-Vela, very low Na i column densities of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 1088FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{8} to 1099FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} can be estimated using the empirical N(H)/N(Na i) formula given by Ferlet et al. (1985), and low color excesses, E(B-ADDOP:minus-V) â‰¤RELOP:less-than-or-equals\leq 0.06, are detected toward d <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc Puppis-Vela sight lines. Very low electron column densities (neğ‘’FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{e} â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 0.03) are also deduced from the dispersion measure of three pulsars within 200 pc (Toscano et al. 1999).

Surrounding the Sun, the LIC, and the G cloud is the Local Bubble (or Cavity). The Local Bubble is an irregularly shaped region that radially extends approximately 70 pc from the Sun (Welsh et al. 1998). The Local Bubble appears to protrude toward Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa [lğ‘™italic-ll = 226Â°, bğ‘italic-bb = -ADDOP:minus-14Â°], forming an extention called the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel and borders the sight lines to Puppis-Vela. The extent of the tunnel is not well determined, and is discussed in detail in Â§6.3. It is not yet known whether the Local Bubble is a bounded region created from a cataclysmic event such as a supernova explosion, or if the Local Bubble is an intercloud region, isolated by the boundaries of neighboring structures (Snowden et al. 1990). The majority of the volume of the Local Bubble is filled with hot X-ray emitting plasma with a characteristic temperature of T âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 1066FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6}K, while most of the mass in the Local Bubble is cool and diffuse (T âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100Â K). Typical densities in the Local Bubble range between âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 0.002 â€“ 500 cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} (for a recent review on this subject see Breitschwerdt (1998)).

section.h2: 3 Using Na i to study the LISM

div.p: There are advantages and disadvantages associated with using Na i to study the LISM. The main advantage of Na i is that it is possible to perform high resolution (R âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100,000) surveys with ground based telescopes. Na i is a tracer of cold, high column density gas since it has a low ionization potential of 5.14 eV. On the other hand, the disadvantage of observing Na i is that it is a trace ion in the ISM. Na i is well suited for mapping the boundaries of hot plasma in the Local Bubble since low column densities of Na i are expected within the Local Bubble and higher column densities are detected without. Additionally, cold clouds are embedded in the hot Local Bubble, and these clouds may be located and mapped with Na i. Estimates on the extent, distance, velocity and Na i column density of previously undocumented components containing neutral gas are presented in Â§6.

The most abundant species in the LISM is H i; however, H i is more difficult to observe since space based instruments must be employed to measure its column density. There are two empirical methods by which column densities of H i may be estimated: the ratio of N(H i):E(B-ADDOP:minus-V) (Bohlin et al. 1978, Diplas & Savage 1994), and the ratio of N(H):N(Na i) (Hobbs 1974a, 1974b, 1976, Stokes 1978, and Ferlet et al. 1985). Neither of these two methods of empirically calculating N(H i) are suitable for the study of the LISM toward Puppis-Vela.

The first method of calculating atomic hydrogen column densities given the color excesses of stars does not produce accurate results for sight lines with very low reddening since the uncertainties associated with the MK spectral type are large compared to the observed values of (B-ADDOP:minus-V). The second method of determining the distribution of hydrogen estimates N(H i + H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}) given column densities of Na i is also inaccurate for regions of low column density. The studies mentioned above contain few data points for N(Na i) â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 101111FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{11} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}. Nearly 80% of the local Puppis-Vela LISM sight lines contain absorption components with column densities below 101111FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{11} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}, the regime where the N(H) to N(Na i) empirical relationship has not been shown to apply. In addition to the lack of data points in the low column density limit, Welty et al. (1994) have also noted that several of the low column density data points are incorrect. The large uncertainty in N(H):N(Na i) in the low column density limit makes it useful for only order of magnitude estimates. As a point of reference, however, direct H i observations along several lines of sight in Puppis-Vela at d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100 pc exhibit log N(H i) â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 18.1 to 20.1 cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} (Table 5.1, Dring 1997).

Na D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} and D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} Î»â¢Î»ğœ†ğœ†italic-lambda italic-lambda\lambda\lambda5889.951, 5895.924 spectra for 11 B-type stars within 200 pc in the direction of the IRAS Vela Shell (lğ‘™italic-ll,bğ‘italic-bb) â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx (263Â°,8Â°) were obtained by M. S. Sahu and A. Blaauw using the CoudÃ© Echelle Spectrograph (CES) on the 1.4 meter CoudÃ© Auxiliary Telescope (CAT) at the European Southern Observatory. The observations were made both on site in La Silla and remotely from Garching in January 1993 (HDâ€‰76805) and January 1994. The Long Camera and the UV-coated Ford Aerospace/Loral 2048 Ã—MULOP:times\times 2048 CCD (#27) were used for all observations. The CCDâ€™s pixel size was 15 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum Ã—MULOP:times\times 15 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum, and had a low dark current of 3 e-FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-}/pixel/hour, a low readout noise (âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 6e-FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-} rms), and few apparent defects. The net efficiency of the system is 3.8% at 5400 Ã…Â and 4.6% at 6450 Ã…Â (Pasquini et al. 1992).

TableÂ 1 contains general stellar information for the 11 stars observed. To supplement the sample, we searched the literature and found five additional stars with Na i column density and velocity measurements in the direction towards Puppis-Vela. The following information is listed for each star: HD number, Galactic position (longitude and latitude), MK spectral type classification, visual magnitude, observed Johnson photometric colors from the Tycho catalogue, calculated Bâ€“V color excess, distance obtained using Hipparcos trigonometric parallax data, heliocentric radial velocity (Vrâ¢aâ¢dsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r italic-a italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{rad}), projected rotational velocities (vâ¢sâ¢iâ¢nâ¢iğ‘£ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–italic-v italic-s italic-i italic-n italic-iv\,sin\,i), and references for the MK spectral type and Vrâ¢aâ¢dsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r italic-a italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{rad}, respectively.

A standard data reduction procedure was followed that first included bias subtraction and flat-fielding of the science spectra. A thorium-argon arc lamp was the wavelength calibration source, and the stability of the CES yielded unchanging calibration exposures throughout each night. The calibration spectra were used in conjunction with the Th-Ar line list by Willmarth (1987) to visually identify the emission lines, fit a second degree polynomial to the resulting pixel vs. wavelength arrays, and thereby convert our absorption line spectra from pixel to wavelength space. The absolute wavelength solutions had rms variations of 0.7 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â or 0.014 Ã…Â for the 1993 spectrum and 1.1 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â or 0.023 Ã…Â for the 1994 spectra. The instrumental resolution determined using the FWHM of the thorium lines for both observing runs was 3.1 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, equivalent to Î»/Î”â¢Î»ğœ†Î”ğœ†italic-lambda MULOP:divide Delta italic-lambda\lambda/\Delta\lambda â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 95,000.

In addition to the interstellar Na i absorption features, the raw spectra were contaminated by many telluric absorption lines which are abundant at wavelengths surrounding the Na i D doublet. Multiple observations of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha Vir (HDâ€‰116658) were made since it is a nearby star with a high rotational velocity (v sin i = 159 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, Hoffleit & Jaschek 1982) and little interstellar Na i absorption. These spectra were used as templates to remove telluric absorption lines contaminating the spectra. To normalize the template spectra, the continuua were fit with cubic splines then divided by the fits. The optical depths of the atmospheric absorption lines in Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha Vir were adjusted by a multiplicative factor for each star so that the strength of the well separated telluric lines at wavelengths of 5883-ADDOP:minus-5901 Ã…Â matched those in each object spectrum. Next, the object spectra were divided by the scaled Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha Vir template spectra to eliminate telluric absorption lines. The observed spectra were continuum normalized by fitting a cubic spline and dividing the object spectrum by the fit. The resulting spectra had signal-to-noise ratios of 110 to 250.

To fit the spectral lines and infer physical properties about the interstellar velocity components along each line of sight, we used the profile fitting method and software developed by Welty, Hobbs, & Kulkarni (1994). This technique assumes that the components have Maxwellian velocity distributions. Each line was fit with the fewest number of components necessary, and additional components either increased the Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} statistic or required that one or more components have unphysical b values. The parameters describing each component were adjusted by an iterative, non-linear, least-square method to achieve an rms deviation of the absorption line fit that was comparable to the rms deviation in the stellar continuum, and reduced the value of the Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} statistic.

The Na i spectra of the 11 stars observed are displayed in FigureÂ 2. For each sight line, normalized intensity is plotted versus heliocentric velocity for both the D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} and D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} lines. Filled circles indicate the data points, the best-fit models are plotted with solid lines, and dashed lines trace the individual Gaussian components. Beneath the D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} spectra are the residuals to the fits for the D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} lines. For the spectra of HDâ€‰72232 and HDâ€‰79416, the y-axes in the residual plots range from -ADDOP:minus-0.1 to 0.1 in units of normalized intensity, whereas for the rest of the spectra, the y-axes of the residual plots range from -ADDOP:minus-0.015 to 0.015. Upwards arrows beneath the D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} lines are located at the projected LIC velocity. No LIC components are revealed in the spectra, as expected (see Â§2).

TableÂ 2 contains numerical data associated with the model fits and includes: (1) the HD number, (2) central heliocentric velocity, (3) equivalent width, (4) Doppler b parameter, (5) logarithm of the Na i column density, (6) signal-to-noise ratio, and (7) the heliocentric to LSR velocity conversion factor. Uncertainties were estimated by comparing the measured Na i D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} and D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} profile fit parameters. If there were no sources of error, these values would be identical since each pair of doublet lines arise due to absorption by the same Na i gas. The maximum difference in measured velocities between a D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} versus D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} component is Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pm0.5 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and is consistent with the calculated rms velocity dispersion. The uncertainties associated with the column density and b value are generally <RELOP:less-than< 10% and a quality estimate is listed for each spectral line in TableÂ 2.

Along the eleven sight lines toward early type stars located within 250Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< lğ‘™italic-ll <RELOP:less-than< 299Â°Â and -ADDOP:minus-8Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< +4Â°, Na i gas is primarily found in one of three distinct velocity ranges (to an accuracy of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 1 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}) . Five additional sight lines with Na i kinematic information were found in the literature. General stellar information for these stars is listed in TableÂ 3. Information about the Na i components observed is in TableÂ 4 and includes: (1) HD number, (2) central heliocentric velocity, (3) Doppler b parameter, (4) logarithm of the Na i column density, (5) velocity resolution at which the observation was made, and (6) a reference for the data.

Although the sixteen lines of sight are spread over âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 50Â°Â in Galactic longitude, the absorption components do not appear at random velocities. The majority of the velocity components can be associated with one of the following velocity ranges: (A) +6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â <RELOP:less-than< Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} <RELOP:less-than< +9 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, (B) +12 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â <RELOP:less-than< Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} <RELOP:less-than< +15 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and (C) +21 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â <RELOP:less-than< Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} <RELOP:less-than< 23 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. The Galactic coordinates of the sixteen lines of sight have been plotted in FigureÂ 3. Filled triangles indicate the locations of stars whose we present new Na i data, while open triangles pinpoint the locations of stars for which data are from the literature. To illustrate the presence of absorption components at the three common velocities described, lines of sight with absorption at velocities A, B, and C have been encircled. No distinction has been made regarding the source of the data in FiguresÂ 3b-3d. The symbol sizes indicate the relative Na i column density detected. Small symbols correspond to 10.0 <RELOP:less-than< log[N(Na i)] <RELOP:less-than< 10.4, medium symbols denote 10.4 <RELOP:less-than< log[N(Na i)] <RELOP:less-than< 11.1, and large symbols represent column densities of 11.7 <RELOP:less-than< log[N(Na i)] <RELOP:less-than< 12.6.

Analysis of the distribution of data points in FigureÂ 3 reveals that velocity components A, B, and C are located at distinct regions in lğ‘™italic-ll and bğ‘italic-bb. The size of the data points, which corresponds to the Na i column density, reveals that higher column densities of gas at velocities A and B exist in this region of the LISM, whereas the sight lines with absorption at velocity C have lower column densities. Comparing the locations where each of the components are detected, the velocities of the components in the Local Standard of Rest decrease with increasing Galactic longitude. General Galactic rotation also follows this trend, but the Galactic rotation velocities calculated at d = 150 pc, assuming a galactocentric distance of 8.5 kpc, and a local circular speed of 220 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â in the solar neighborhood (Mihalas & Binney 1981), do not match up with the velocities of Na i absorption features observed in the LISM. The sightlines to stars at d >RELOP:greater-than> 200 pc confirm the locations of local gas absorption for components B and C, whereas the region 280Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg <RELOP:less-than< lğ‘™italic-ll <RELOP:less-than< 300Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg, where component A is detected, is outside of the sample area. Also from the spectra of the more distant sight lines, absorption features at the velocity of Component B were additionally observed along sightlines with bğ‘italic-bb â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-toRELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsim -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg and lğ‘™italic-ll â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-toRELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsim 260Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg, and gas with velocities coincident with Component C was observed up to the Galactic plane (bğ‘italic-bb â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 0Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg).

In Figure 4 the Puppis-Vela region is viewed from above the Galactic plane and contains the same data points as FigureÂ 3. Here, distance increases radially outward and galactic longitude increases counterclockwise. The symbol sizes are defined identically as in FigureÂ 3, and the same Galactic latitude range is applied: -ADDOP:minus-10Â°<RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< +5Â°. The symbols in FigureÂ 4 indicate the velocity of the absorption component, and have been placed at the appropriate distance and galactic longitude of the target star. From this perspective, the locations of components with similar velocities are also seen to be grouped together, and not randomly distributed. Arcs have been overplotted to highlight the maximum distance and minimum extent in Galactic longitude of the front edge of a gas component at a particular velocity. The arcs have been labled with â€œA,â€ â€œB,â€ or â€œCâ€ to match the velocity ranges defined above and on the plot. Note that the arc labeled â€œCâ€ is dashed in the center to indicate where its presence is uncertain according to the spectra presented here, but when spectra from more distant stars are included, gas with velocity C is seen throughout the entire Galactic longitude range.

The locations and characteristics of the three components are summarized in TableÂ 5. For each component, TableÂ 5 lists the minimum extent in Galactic longitude and latitude where the gas is observed, the maximum distance to the gas, the heliocentric velocity range of the gas, and the spread in Na i column densities for spectral lines within the given velocity range. Three stars (HDâ€‰61831, HDâ€‰65575, and HDâ€‰74195) have been omitted from Figure 4 for reasons discussed in Â§6.3.

Sight lines either pass completely through the component, or partially penetrate the gas. Using the distribution of the measured column densities towards the target stars of known distances, it is possible to deduce limits on the distances to each gas component. Refining these distance estimates would necessarily require more observations (âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 18 additional sight lines exist) to obtain a finer distribution of observations so that the boundaries of the gas and the density distribution of the gas within the components could be distinguished. Specific characteristics of the gas at velocities A, B, and C are suggested below.

The three components of gas observed in the LISM have unique characteristics. Sight lines with velocity A gas exhibit rather high column densities (large symbols) along three out of four sight lines. These three high column density sight lines (#1, 3, 8) are located at Galactic latitudes of -ADDOP:minus-4.9Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< -ADDOP:minus-3.0Â°, while the fourth target whose spectrum exhibits gas with velocity A is at bğ‘italic-bb = +3.8Â°. Since the latitude of the latter target, HDâ€‰106490, is on average 8Â°Â away from the others, a smaller column density of gas at Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\small helio}Â = +6 to +9 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â exists above the galactic plane towards HDâ€‰106490 (#2). The absorbing material is confined to a distance <RELOP:less-than< 100 pc since the column density of Na i does not increase when more distant sight lines are observed.

Sight lines with components at velocity B tend to have moderate to high column densities at larger distances. Toward the stars HDâ€‰79416 (#9) and HDâ€‰72232 (#10) we find log N(Na i)Â âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\simÂ 11.8, whereas the remainder of the sight lines with absorption at velocity B ranged from log N(Na i) = 10.28 to 11.08. Towards one of the seven stars with spectral features at velocity B, HDâ€‰74560 has a low column density (small symbol), yet it is physically located between several stars that have substantially higher column densities. This variation in the magnitude of the column densities suggests that the velocity B gas is patchy, and inhomogeneous. The high column density along the line of sight towards HDâ€‰74195 (#8), observed by Welsh et al. (1994), reveals gas at velocity B, however the Doppler parameter given, b = 0.3Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pm0.1 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}â€‰ is small compared to the 3.6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â velocity resolution, so this data point has been omitted from our analysis.

There are two concentrations of sight lines with velocity C gas: one at lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 270Â°Â and one at lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 252Â°. Low column densities (small symbols) are observed towards the stars grouped at lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 270Â°Â while moderate column densities (medium symbols) are seen toward lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 252Â°. Stars HDâ€‰74146 (#5), HDâ€‰74071 (#6), and HDâ€‰74560 (#7) may be located near the edge of the component or the component may be very diffuse considering the low values of N(Na i) detected.

Because of the absence of observed sight lines with d <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc, the arc tracing the estimated boundary of velocity C gas is dashed in the middle. Three nearby stars are located behind the dashed portion of the arc but do not exhibit absorption by gas at velocity C in their Na i spectra. As noted above, it is likely that the gas is patchy and inhomogeneous, which would then account for the observations. The presence of component C in the spectra of the longer sight lines in the sample is also intermittant, also indicating that the component C gas is patchy. One of these stars, HDâ€‰79416 (#10), is located above the Galactic plane at bğ‘italic-bb = +3.3Â°, while all of the stars revealing velocity C gas have bğ‘italic-bb â‰¤RELOP:less-than-or-equals\leq -ADDOP:minus-5.9Â°. The spectra from the more distant stars in our sample include component C gas for bğ‘italic-bb â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 0Â°Â°Â°\arcdeg and for the same extent in lğ‘™italic-ll.

With the components of neutral Na i gas arising in the first 200 pc of the ISM toward Puppis-Vela identified, any subsequent spectroscopic study of the neutral ISM in this direction can distinguish between local gas and more distant gas. The presence of absorption components at velocities A, B, or C in the spectra of future studies will not be confused with absorption due to the myriad other structures that exist toward Puppis-Vela. The three dimensional information about the componentsâ€“the extent of the gas as projected on the sky, and the limits on the distance to the gasâ€“serve as a basis of estimating the typical velocities and column densities present in the LISM.

In general, the LISM toward Puppis-Vela has low positive velocities ranging from +6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â to +23 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Absorbing gas at these velocities is located at distances closer than âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 104 pc, and the Na i column densities detected range from log N = 10.2 cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} to 11.9 cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} indicating that the cold gas is clumpy or patchy, and not uniformly distributed.

To put our results in perspective, we searched the literature for UV interstellar absorption line studies in the direction of Puppis-Vela in order to demonstrate that knowing the properties of the LISM gas in a particular region of the sky is extremely valuable for the interpretation of longer lines of sight. The only recent study has been toward Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Velorum by Fitzpatrick & Spitzer (1994; hereafter FS94). Their Hubble Space Telescope (HST)/Goddard High-Resolution Spectrograph (GHRS) observations have a velocity resolution similar to our Na i data (3.1 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â versus 3.5 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â for the GHRS data) facilitating a comparison between the two datasets. Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Velorum is located at [(lğ‘™italic-ll = 263Â°, bğ‘italic-bb = -8Â°); dğ‘‘italic-dd â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 260 pc] so it is likely that some of the components observed in the GHRS spectra arise in the LISM. FS94 detect seven components as described in TableÂ 6. Comparing the velocities of the FS94 features with the three velocity components we detect in the LISM, their component 6 corresponds to our component C and their components 4 and 5 correspond to our component B.

The neutral species detected with GHRS include S i and C i. FS94 fit the S i spectrum with component 4, and the C i feature with components 2 and 4. In addition to these neutral species, we also include a Na i spectrum of Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel that was obtained at the same time and with the same instruments as the LISM data toward Puppis-Vela described in Â§4. The Na i D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} and D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} spectra of Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel are shown in FigureÂ 5, and the parameters of the fit are listed in TableÂ 7. Na i absorption is seen at velocities corresponding to FS94 components 2, 4, and 6. Comparing the Na i data for the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel line of sight with the distribution of gas in the foreground, we may conclude that component 2 arises in gas located beyond 200 pc, yet less than 260 pcâ€”the distance to Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel. Both components 4 and 6 were detected in the LISM at distances <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc.

The presence of component 4 is complicated, however, by the fact that it appears in the spectra of all of the species detected in FS94, both neutral and highly ionized, and in our Na i spectrum. In addition, FS94 note that a Copernicus spectrum toward Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel reveals H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} absorption which may be assigned to either component 4 or a blend of components 2 and 5. Although FS94 assign H ii region origins to component 4 absorption because of the presence of species such as C iv and Si iv, it is difficult to reconcile neutrals and molecules coexisting with such highly ionized species.

FS94 propose that the H ii region containing the component 4 gas is the âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 40 pc surrounding a âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 60 pc-radius stellar wind blown bubble centered on Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel. We suggest that there are two distinct regions of gas with velocities matching component 4. First, the ionized region extending Â 100 pc from the star described in FS94 contains ionized gas at Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 13 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Second, the neutral gas absorption along the line of sight to Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel at Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 13 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â occurs at d â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 115 pc, corresponding with our component B. If the H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} spectrum is fit by component 4, then it is consistent to place the H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} gas with the Na i in component B, thereby providing a unique example of H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} gas near the edge, or possibly within, the Local Bubble.

Not only is the mapping of the nearby gas essential in the characterization of the LISM itself, this data clarified the complex absorption signature along the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} Vel line of sight, and should prove useful for other Puppis-Vela sight lines. Caution must be observed, however, since it has been shown here and in other papers (Watson & Meyer (1996); Frail et al. (1994); Lauroesch et al. (1998, 1999)) that interstellar Na i is patchy, as evidenced by the subparsec-scale structures that appear to be ubiquitous in the diffuse ISM, but this focused study will detect most components specific to the Puppis-Vela LISM which previous all-sky local gas surveys ignored.

section.h3: 6.3 LISM Absorption Components at Peculiar Velocities

div.p: Of the 27 absorption features detected (excluding the ultra-high resolution data of Dunkin & Crawford (1999)) along 16 lines of sight, 9 features have velocities outside of velocities A, B, and C. The peculiar velocities of all but three components can be understood with simple explanations. A total of three absorption components toward HDâ€‰61831 and HDâ€‰72232 lie just outside of the velocity ranges A, B, and C. It is likely that these absorption features are blends of multiple narrow lines that are unresolved at R âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100,000, as evidenced by the many components distinguished in the ultra-high resolution data towards HDâ€‰81188 cited in TableÂ 4. Three additional components toward HDâ€‰65575 and HDâ€‰106490 have peculiar velocities, but these stars are located at the periphery of the sample, and it is natural that at some point the characteristics of the gas change and components A, B, and C cease being detected.

In total, only 3 of 27 components cannot be simply accounted for, and they include the Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +132.3 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â and -ADDOP:minus-10.6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â lines toward HDâ€‰62226 and the Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-139 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â line toward HDâ€‰74146. The spectra of HDâ€‰62226 and HDâ€‰74146 are plotted in FigureÂ 6a and 5b, respectively. For each line of sight, the Na i D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} absorption is plotted at the top, the D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} absorption is plotted in the middle of the panel. The residual to the best fit to the D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} spectrum is on the bottom, plotted with the y-axis ranging from -ADDOP:minus-0.015 to +0.015. Unlike the spectra of the other LISM sight lines in this region, that of HDâ€‰62226 contains three components at three distinct velocities. The absorption at Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +22.2 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â is consistent with the gas observed towards adjacent sight lines in the region, but the absorption features at Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-10.6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â and +132.2 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â are not observed towards any other stars in the area.

Although lines of sight adjacent to HDâ€‰62226 were also observed, namely HDâ€‰61878, HDâ€‰64503, and HDâ€‰61831, the spectra toward these stars do not show absorption at either Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-10.6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â or +132.2 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Because the sight line towards HDâ€‰62226 is fortuitously flanked by these three nearby lines of sight that have also been observed, it may be concluded that the gas producing the Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-10.6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â and +132.2 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â components are confined to a small region projected on the sky at d <RELOP:less-than< 190 pc. The Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-10.6 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â component is very weak, but is clearly visible in both the D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} and D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} spectra. The D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}/D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} ratio of equivalent widths for the +132.2 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â lines equals 2.2, which is close to the expected ratio of 2 for unsaturated Na i D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} and D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} lines.

The other sight line with unexplained components is that of HDâ€‰74146 which also contains an absorption component at a high velocity, but here the feature is a broad (b = 16.7 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}) line at negative velocity, Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-139 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}/D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} = 0.8. The breadth of the line and the low D22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}/D11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} ratio are atypical of unsaturated interstellar lines, and it is unlikely that such a weak line could be saturated. Additionally, several sight lines adjacent to HDâ€‰74146 were also observed (HDâ€‰76805, HDâ€‰74071, and HDâ€‰74560) though their spectra did not reveal absorption at high negative velocities.

A literature search for information regarding whether or not circumstellar material has been observed around HDâ€‰62226 or HDâ€‰74146 yielded nothing. Additionally, we attempted to use International Ultraviolet Explorer (IUE) spectra to determine the origin of the high velocity absorption features. HDâ€‰74146 was not observed with IUE, and only one high dispersion spectrum of HDâ€‰62226 was obtained. The single spectrum toward HDâ€‰62226 had a low signal-to-noise ratio (S/N <RELOP:less-than< 10), so the presence or absence of high velocity features associated with characteristic circumstellar or interstellar absorption could not be ascertained. With the data available, we were not able to determine whether the high velocity features in the spectra of HDâ€‰62226 and HDâ€‰74146 were of circumstellar or interstellar origin.

In Â§2 it was mentioned that the extension of the Local Bubble (or Cavity) known as the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel is adjacent to Puppis-Vela when projected on the sky. This tunnel of rarefied hot gas has been estimated to extend âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim250-300 pc (Sfeir et al. 1999; Welsh 1991; Welsh, Crifo, & Lallement 1998), and appears to be almost free of neutral gas. For instance, H i column densities of N(H i) âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 101818FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:18 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{18} cm -22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} measured toward the 153Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pm15 pc line of sight to Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa are thought to arise primarily in gas along the first âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim5 pcâ€”within the LIC (Gry et al. 1985). In this section, previous estimates of the tunnelâ€™s extent will be reviewed and a new measurement of the size of the tunnel, within the first 150 pc, will be presented.

After the low gas densities towards several stars in the direction of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa were noticed, subsequent studies of the LISM probed adjacent sight lines to ascertain the size of the tunnel. Using optical absorption spectroscopy to observe the Na i D doublet, three estimates of the extent of the tunnel were made. First, Welsh (1991) assigned minimum angular dimensions to the tunnel: an elliptical hole located at 226Â°Â â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim lğ‘™italic-ll â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 242Â°, -ADDOP:minus-11Â°Â â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim bğ‘italic-bb â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim -ADDOP:minus-20Â°, extending to a depth of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim300 pc. Later Welsh, Crifo, & Lallement (1998) revised the size of the tunnel and substantially widened the estimate. They reported minimum approximate dimensions of the low gas density tunnel towards Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa to be 250 pc long by 90 pc wide. Analysis of Figure 2 in Welsh et al. indicates that the tunnel narrows at larger distances; specifically, the extent of the tunnel is 210Â°Â â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim lğ‘™italic-ll â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 277 Â°Â at d = 150 pc, while at d = 250 pc regions of higher column density gas bound the tunnel to within 215Â°Â â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim lğ‘™italic-ll â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim 240Â°. Sfeir et al. (1999) included the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel in their maps of the neutral gas associated with the Local Bubble, but used only a few data points to confine the low gas density tunnel. Their data is inconclusive regarding the depth of the tunnel and they proposed that the tunnel is either terminated at a distance of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 250 pc by Na i absorbing gas producing equivalent widths of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 50 mÃ…, or that the boundary of the tunnel is closer but contains several perforations.

The maps illustrating the tunnel in Welsh et al. (1998) and Sfeir et al. (1999) do not represent differences in the starsâ€™ Galactic latitude, however. Both papers show the tunnel on plots of distance versus Galactic longitude with the stars projected onto the Galactic plane, thus obscuring information regarding the Galactic latitude of the target stars. Almost all of the published Na i spectral data in the direction of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa pertain to stars below the Galactic plane at bğ‘italic-bb âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â to -ADDOP:minus-30Â°. Our observations add a new dimension to the tunnel boundary since the target stars in our sample are concentrated within bğ‘italic-bb âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â to 0Â°.

In addition to the Na i column density measurements given in TablesÂ 2 and 4 for stars toward Puppis-Vela, N(Na i) measurements along sight lines in and around the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel were compiled. Stellar information (as was given in TableÂ 1) about these published sight lines is in TableÂ 8, and the corresponding Na i column densities and references are in TableÂ 9.

The column densities toward sight lines listed in TablesÂ 2, 4, and 9 and projected onto the Galactic plane are illustrated as a function of distance and Galactic longitude, in FigureÂ 7. The Galactic latitudes of the lines of sight have been divided into two groups: those at -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< 0Â°Â are indicated with filled symbols, while targets located at -ADDOP:minus-30Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â are plotted using open symbols. Diamonds are used when precise measurements of the Na i column density are known and triangles are plotted for sight lines where only N(Na i) upper limits have been determined. The symbol sizes suggest the relative column density detected along each line of sight, with larger symbols indicating larger column densities, as defined in the caption to FigureÂ 3.

The thin solid lines in FigureÂ 7 depict the longitudinal angular extent of the tunnel estimated by Welsh (1991). In view of the data shown in FigureÂ 7, it appears that his estimate should be expanded by âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 5Â°Â on either edge out to a distance of â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 150 pc. Note that all of the sight lines supporting this tunnel estimate have bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< -ADDOP:minus-10Â°. So far, no observations have been made to constrain the tunnelâ€™s extent in latitude or length. The expanded extent of the tunnel proposed by Welsh et al. (1998) (in their Figure 2) is sketched in FigureÂ 6 with dotted lines. With the additional lines of sight near the Galactic plane presented here, the Welsh et al. high longitude tunnel boundary appears misplaced. Either one or more of the following reasons may account for this. The new data reveals that the first âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 150 pc of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel do not extend beyond l â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 267Â°, near the plane of the Galaxy (-ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< 0Â°). There is no data to confirm if the tunnel does or does not extend beyond lğ‘™italic-ll = 267Â°Â for -ADDOP:minus-30Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< -ADDOP:minus-10Â°. At distances of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 150 to 200 pc, the tunnel does not extend beyond lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 251Â°Â near the plane of the Galaxy, as evidenced by the filled data points at lğ‘™italic-ll >RELOP:greater-than> 250Â°Â in FigureÂ 7. There is no observational evidence to determine whether the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel extends past lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 250Â°Â at lower Galactic latitudes, since no sight lines have been observed there. The lower Galactic longitude boundary also appears to encompass sight lines with high Na i column densities, and should be relocated to lğ‘™italic-ll â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-toRELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsim 215Â°. From the compilation of data on almost 40 lines of sight, it appears that outside the Local Bubble (d >RELOP:greater-than> 70 pc), low neutral gas densities are to be found between lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 215Â°Â to 250Â°Â and bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-21Â°Â to -ADDOP:minus-9 Â°. The arc drawn in FigureÂ 7 at d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 150 pc illustrates the extent in Galactic longitude over which low column density lines of sight with bğ‘italic-bb â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssim -ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â have been observed. The arrows pointing to larger distances suggest that this bound on the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel is only a lower limit, but is dictated by the present data.

The most distant sight lines included in this sample have d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 200 pc and bğ‘italic-bb âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim -ADDOP:minus-30Â°. At this limit, the sight lines have not penetrated the scale height of the disk of the Galaxy (see Dame & Thaddeus (1994) and Dickey & Lockman (1990)). Studies of more distant sight lines attempting to map the distant end of the tunnel could easily be confused by the Galactic diskâ€™s decreasing density gradient, whereby stars at large distances and lower latitudes might exhibit lower N(Na i) measurements because of the geometry of the Galaxy, and not necessarily because of extensions in the Local Bubble. From nearby interstellar Na i measurements, there is a region of low density towards Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa, but it is not clear whether the tunnel is present in the plane of the Galaxy. Additional observations along sight lines 0Â°Â to 30Â°Â below the Galactic plane are needed to clarify the three dimensional extent of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel.

We have presented high resolution Na i spectra toward 11 early type stars plus kinematic data for 5 lines of sight taken from the literature to study the LISM in the direction of Puppis-Vela. Additionally, we have compiled a list of Na i column density measurements made toward nearby (d <RELOP:less-than< 200 pc) sight lines in the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel. Our conclusions are stated below:

1. Observations of Na i in the LISM toward Puppis-Vela revealed absorption at three distinct velocities with the following properties: Component Aâ€”[lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 276Â°Â to 298Â°, bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-5Â°Â to +4Â°], Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +6 to +9 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 104 pc; Component Bâ€”[lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 264Â°Â to 276Â°, bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-7Â°Â to +3Â°], Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +12 to +15 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 115 pc; Component Câ€”[lğ‘™italic-ll â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 252Â°Â to 271Â°, bğ‘italic-bb â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx -ADDOP:minus-8Â°Â to -ADDOP:minus-6Â°], Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +21 to +23 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and d âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 131 pc. This identification of LISM gas will enable future studies of the Puppis-Vela ISM to separate local gas absorption from more distant features, as was illustrated for the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} line of sight. Including a distinction of the distance at which gas exists, as well as its position on the sky, is a fundamental step in the new field of three dimensional astronephography.

2. The LIC is not detected in Na i absorption toward Puppis-Vela because the column densities of LIC gas in this direction are too low, generally <RELOP:less-than< 101111FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{11} cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}.

3. Low column density sight lines in the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel are confined to lğ‘™italic-ll = 215Â°Â to 250Â°Â and bğ‘italic-bb = -ADDOP:minus-21Â°Â to -ADDOP:minus-9Â°, to a distance of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 150 pc. New observations closer to the Galactic plane (-ADDOP:minus-10Â°Â <RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< 0Â°) reveal higher column densities suggesting that the tunnel may not extend in latitude to bğ‘italic-bb = 0Â°. More observations near the Galactic plane and at distances greater than 150 pc are needed to ascertain the true size and location of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel.

4. Although most of the absorption components seen in the spectra of stars within 200 pc toward Puppis-Vela could be assigned to one of the three components, A, B, or C, a few components had peculiar velocities. Toward HDâ€‰62226 and HDâ€‰74146 high velocity features, Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = +132.2 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â and Vhâ¢eâ¢lâ¢iâ¢oâ„ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘œFLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-e italic-l italic-i italic-o FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{helio} = -ADDOP:minus-139 â€‰kmâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â respectively, were present. In both cases, nearby sight lines were also observed and contained no high velocity features. The origin of the high velocity gas components, be they circumstellar or interstellar, is unknown.

FigureÂ 1. A schematic diagram of the structures immediately surrounding the Sun. The Sun (at center) is embedded in the LIC and near the G cloud, which are both within the Local Bubble. Approximate locations, sizes, and angles subtended by the clouds are given by Linsky et al. (1999) and Lallement (1998). The velocities of the LIC and G cloud shown are with respect to the heliocentric frame of reference. The arrow extending from the Sun shows the direction of the motion of the Sun relative to the Local Standard of Rest (LSR). Dashed lines indicate the approximate angle subtended by Puppis-Vela.

The bottom panel for each line of sight shows the residuals to the fits with the y-axis ranging from -ADDOP:minus-0.1 to +0.1 for HDâ€‰72232 and HDâ€‰79416, and the y-axis ranging from -ADDOP:minus-0.015 to +0.015 for all other lines of sight. FigureÂ 7. Na i absorption line data in the direction of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel. The solid lines confine the first 200 pc of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel as proposed by Welsh (1991) and the dotted lines outline the first 200 pc of the tunnel described in Welsh et al. (1998). The thick arc highlights the longitudinal extent of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta CMa tunnel according to the compilation of the data and pertains to the region below the Galactic plane where -ADDOP:minus-30Â°<RELOP:less-than< bğ‘italic-bb <RELOP:less-than< -ADDOP:minus-10Â°.
